Massachusetts General Laws, Chapter 208,.proposition: Provides for the modification of custody orders upon a showing of a substantial change in circumstances.

Yannas v. Frondistou-Yannas, 395 Mass. 7.proposition: Establishes the standard for modification of custody orders.
Yannas v. Frondistou-Yannas, 395 Mass. 7.support_reasoning: The case does not set the standard for modification of custody orders. Yannas addresses the standard for a custodial parent’s removal of children from the Commonwealth under G.L. c. 208, § 30, adopting the “real advantage” test in the context of an initial custody/relocation determination in a divorce judgment. It does not discuss the requirements or threshold (e.g., material change of circumstances) for later modification of an existing custody order.
Yannas v. Frondistou-Yannas, 395 Mass. 7.relevant_excerpt: “The Massachusetts removal statute, G. L. c. 208, § 30 (1984 ed.), provides that … ‘[a] minor child of divorced parents … shall not … be removed out of this commonwealth … unless the court upon cause shown otherwise orders.’ The words ‘upon cause shown’ mean only that removal must be in the best interests of the child (Rubin v. Rubin, 370 Mass. 857 [1976]; Hale v. Hale, supra at 815), and thus the central question in this case is how these ‘best interests’ are to be determined.”

Custody of Vaillancourt, 54 Mass. App. C.raw_text: Custody of Vaillancourt, 54 Mass. App. Ct. 383 (2002)
Custody of Vaillancourt, 54 Mass. App. C.proposition: Affirms the principle that the child's best interests are paramount in custody modification cases.
Custody of Vaillancourt, 54 Mass. App. C.support_reasoning: The opinion is not a custody modification case and does not analyze or articulate a standard about the paramountcy of the child’s best interests in that context. It concerns enforcement of a separation agreement, allocation of support as alimony vs. child support, SSDI credit, and contempt; custody/visitation is mentioned only tangentially and without discussion of a ‘best interests’ standard. Thus, it does not provide authority for the claimed proposition.
Custody of Vaillancourt, 54 Mass. App. C.relevant_excerpt:
The memorandum also contained numerous other provisions pertaining to the division of marital assets, the husband’s visitation rights, the maintenance of various medical and life insurance policies, and various other rights and responsibilities of the parties.
...
Moreover, even if the court had reached such a result in Rosenberg, it would not apply where, as here, the parties had specifically provided in a marital separation agreement that the noncustodial spouse would not be entitled to a credit for past SSDI benefits put aside for his daughter’s education. Such agreements may be enforced so long as they are fair and reasonable, regardless of the rules that might otherwise apply.

Custody of Kali, 439 Mass. 834 (2003).proposition: Emphasizes the importance of the child's wishes in custody modification proceedings.
Custody of Kali, 439 Mass. 834 (2003).support_reasoning: The opinion is focused on articulating and applying the statutory and common-law ‘best interests of the child’ standard and the importance of stability and the primary-caregiver relationship, not the child’s stated wishes. The court does not discuss Kali’s preferences or treat a child’s expressed wishes as a significant factor in custody or custody-modification analysis. Accordingly, it does not emphasize the importance of the child’s wishes in custody modification proceedings and is a poor citation for that proposition.
Custody of Kali, 439 Mass. 834 (2003).relevant_excerpt: “In custody matters, the touchstone inquiry of what is ‘best for the child’ is firmly rooted in American history… The required considerations of the second paragraph of G. L. c. 209C, § 10 (a), neither replace the ‘best interests of the child’ standard nor limit the factors that a judge may consider in determining what custodial arrangements are in the best interests of the child… If the parenting arrangement in which a child has lived is satisfactory and is reasonably capable of preservation, it is ordinarily in the child’s best interests to maintain that arrangement…”

Adoption of Talik, 84 Mass. App. Ct. 644.raw_text: Adoption of Talik, 84 Mass. App. Ct. 644 (2014)
Adoption of Talik, 84 Mass. App. Ct. 644.proposition: Discusses the factors considered in modifying custody arrangements.
Adoption of Talik, 84 Mass. App. Ct. 644.support_reasoning: The opinion concerns dismissal of indictments based on prosecutorial misconduct and the integrity of grand jury proceedings. It analyzes the Mayfield factors for dismissing indictments and the sufficiency of grand jury evidence; it does not address child custody, guardianship, or modification of custody arrangements. Therefore it does not support the proposition about factors considered in modifying custody arrangements.
Adoption of Talik, 84 Mass. App. Ct. 644.relevant_excerpt: “Although generally the adequacy or competency of evidence before a grand jury is not a matter for judicial inquiry . . . , we will consider whether the evidence before the grand jury was sufficient to support a finding of probable cause . . . and whether the defendant has shown that the integrity of the grand jury proceedings was impaired . . . .”

Custody of Carney, 65 Mass. App. Ct. 316.raw_text: Custody of Carney, 65 Mass. App. Ct. 316 (2006)
Custody of Carney, 65 Mass. App. Ct. 316.proposition: Considers the impact of a parent's circumstances on the child's well-being in custody modifications.
Custody of Carney, 65 Mass. App. Ct. 316.support_reasoning: This opinion is not a custody or family-law case and does not discuss a parent's circumstances, a child's well-being, or standards for custody modification. It concerns subdivision approval, easements, and standing in a land-use dispute. Therefore it does not support the proposition about considering a parent's circumstances on a child's well-being in custody modifications.
Custody of Carney, 65 Mass. App. Ct. 316.relevant_excerpt: Because the proposed subdivision of the Wildes parcel relies on access over the Shallow Pond subdivision roadways as its sole means of access to a public way, it rests on a flawed essential premise and must be annulled. See Parker v. Black Brook Realty Corp., 61 Mass. App. Ct. 308, 310-311 (2004). See generally North Landers Corp. v. Planning Bd. of Falmouth, 382 Mass. 432, 436-437 (1981).

Custody of Derrick, 52 Mass. App. Ct. 28.raw_text: Custody of Derrick, 52 Mass. App. Ct. 280 (2001)
Custody of Derrick, 52 Mass. App. Ct. 28.proposition: Addresses the importance of maintaining parent-child relationships in custody modifications.
Custody of Derrick, 52 Mass. App. Ct. 28.support_reasoning: The provided opinion is not Custody of Derrick but Commonwealth v. Dolliver, an OUI case about peremptory jury challenges and breathalyzer-related jury instructions. It does not concern child custody, parent-child relationships, or standards for modifying custody orders. Therefore, it cannot support a proposition about the importance of maintaining parent-child relationships in custody modifications.
Custody of Derrick, 52 Mass. App. Ct. 28.relevant_excerpt: This opinion discusses peremptory challenges and breathalyzer instructions in an OUI prosecution and contains no discussion of custody, parents, children, or family relationships; thus there is no relevant excerpt supporting the claimed proposition.

Goodridge v. Department of Public Health.raw_text: Goodridge v. Department of Public Health, 440 Mass. 309 (2003)
Goodridge v. Department of Public Health.proposition: Recognizes the evolving nature of family relationships in custody matters.
Goodridge v. Department of Public Health.case_name: Goodridge v. Department of Public Health
Goodridge v. Department of Public Health.support_reasoning: The case is a marriage-equality decision focused on constitutional liberty and equality in access to civil marriage. While it does discuss evolving concepts of marriage and family and notes changing family structures, it does not address custody standards, custody disputes, or how courts should evaluate family relationships specifically in custody matters. Therefore it does not provide authority for the specific proposition about the evolving nature of family relationships in custody law.
Goodridge v. Department of Public Health.relevant_excerpt: “The demographic changes of the past century make it difficult to speak of an average American family. The composition of families varies greatly from household to household. Massachusetts has responded supportively to ‘the changing realities of the American family’ … and has moved vigorously to strengthen the modern family in its many variations.”

Custody of Zia, 85 Mass. App. Ct. 549 (2.raw_text: Custody of Zia, 85 Mass. App. Ct. 549 (2014)
Custody of Zia, 85 Mass. App. Ct. 549 (2.proposition: Discusses the criteria for modifying a custody order to promote the child's best interests.
Custody of Zia, 85 Mass. App. Ct. 549 (2.case_name: Deadrick v. Zoning Board of Appeals of Chatham
Custody of Zia, 85 Mass. App. Ct. 549 (2.support_reasoning: This opinion is a Massachusetts zoning and land-use decision about nonconforming structures, special permits, and variances. It does not concern family law, custody, or standards for modifying custody orders in the best interests of a child. The case therefore does not address, much less discuss, criteria for modifying a custody order to promote a child’s best interests.
Custody of Zia, 85 Mass. App. Ct. 549 (2.relevant_excerpt: “In resolving this dispute, we are again called on to interpret the ‘difficult and infelicitous’ language of the first two sentences of G. L. c. 40A, § 6, as they pertain to single or two-family residential structures.”

Custody of Chanel, 457 Mass. 120 (2010).proposition: Considers the impact of parental conflict on custody modifications.
Custody of Chanel, 457 Mass. 120 (2010).support_reasoning: The opinion is an employment discrimination and workers’ compensation retaliation case concerning reasonable accommodation and definition of a ‘qualified handicapped person.’ It does not involve child custody, parenting time, or custody modification standards, nor does it analyze the impact of parental conflict on custody decisions. The citation to this case for a proposition about parental conflict and custody modification is therefore incorrect and out of context.
Custody of Chanel, 457 Mass. 120 (2010).relevant_excerpt: Pursuant to G. L. c. 15IB, § 4 (16), it is unlawful for an employer “to dismiss from employment or refuse to hire, rehire or advance in employment or otherwise discriminate against, because of his handicap, any person alleging to be a qualified handicapped person, capable of performing the essential functions of the position involved with reasonable accommodation, unless the employer can demonstrate that the accommodation required to be made to the physical or mental limitations of the person would impose an undue hardship to the employer’s business.”
